IN lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">MAY JEFF BEZOS gave an hour-long presentation on his vision for lass="word-wrap-span">humanity’s future in space: a series of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">artificial settlements in orbit that would be home to as many as 1m people each. Mr Bezos was talking in his role as founder of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Blue lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Origin, a privately held rocket-launch firm. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But he also referred to the company for which he is better known, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Amazon.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Amazon would never have existed, he said, without pre-existing lass="word-wrap-span">infrastructure: postal services to deliver packages; home computers to order lass="word-wrap-span">goods; credit cards to make payments. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The job of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The current generation would be to build an lass="word-wrap-span">equivalent “lass="word-wrap-span">infrastructure” for space. Mr Bezos identified two elements of this: much lower launch costs and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">exploitation of resources in space. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But he might have mentioned anolass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther, more basic requirement for enterprise: a proper legal environment.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">What rules lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There are lass="word-wrap-span">largely date from lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The cold-war era. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Outer lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Treaty of 1967 is lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">foundational lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space-law text. It sets out some basic principles, among lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them that lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space is free for lass="word-wrap-span">exploration and use by all states, and that no claims of sovereignty can be made. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Later agreements lass="word-wrap-span">assign liability for damage caused by lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space objects and require states to help rescue lass="word-wrap-span">astronauts in lass="word-wrap-span">distress.

A common thread runs through lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">These texts. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They all lass="word-wrap-span">assume that space is a realm lass="word-wrap-span">dominated by states, not by companies, let alone individual lass="word-wrap-span">billionaires. As space industrialises, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The gaps in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The law are becoming clearer. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Two areas of concern stand out: lass="word-wrap-span">debris and resource lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">extraction.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Debris is much lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The more pressing issue. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">NASA, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America’s space agency, already tracks more than 500,000 pieces of space junk in orbit around lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Items that are smaller than a marble are not yet tracked but lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">NASA reckons lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There are millions; and at velocities of more than 27,000km per hour, even a lass="word-wrap-span">fleck of paint can cause damage. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Systems are in place to reduce lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The risk of lass="word-wrap-span">collisions (“lass="word-wrap-span">conjunction risk” in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The understated lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">argot of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The satellite industry). lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Firms that launch objects into space need licences from lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The relevant national authorities. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">These regulators are meant to vet proposed orbits and set end-of-life rules for old satellites eilass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther to re-enter lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth’s atmosphere, where lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They burn up, or to be propelled into “lass="word-wrap-span">graveyard slots” where lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There is no risk of lass="word-wrap-span">collision.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">International lass="word-wrap-span">guidelines, based on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American standards, specify best practices for mitigating lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The risk of lass="word-wrap-span">debris. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America’s lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Surveillance lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Network shares some data on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The trajectory of lass="word-wrap-span">larger bits of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space junk. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">International lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Telecommunication lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Union (ITU), a UN agency, responsible among olass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther things for allocating radio frequencies in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space, acts as a clearing-house for information on satellites in orbit.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Put your lass="word-wrap-span">helmet on

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The current system is, in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The words of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Alexandre Vallet of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The ITU, less a binding framework than “a gentlemen’s agreement”. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">End-of-life rules vary between regulators. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">guidelines on lass="word-wrap-span">debris mitigation are not lass="word-wrap-span">enforceable lass="word-wrap-span">internationally. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When satellites are on a crash course, demanding lass="word-wrap-span">large changes in orbit, as happens perhaps once or twice a year, common sense is what stops a lass="word-wrap-span">collision. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">States lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Themselves are free to ignore norms of lass="word-wrap-span">good behaviour. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">India caused both outrage and a fresh lass="word-wrap-span">debris field in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">March by conducting an anti-satellite missile test; lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">China increased lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The amount of trackable lass="word-wrap-span">debris lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then in space by 25% with a single such test in 2007 (see chart on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The next page, which covers bigger objects, with a lass="word-wrap-span">diameter of more than about 10cms). lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">This system has worked well enough so far. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The problems are becoming more lass="word-wrap-span">complex. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">First, launch lass="word-wrap-span">capabilities are spreading. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">last year an lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American startup called lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Swarm Technologies paid a footling $900,000 fine for slass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ending four tiny satellites into orbit on an lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Indian rocket, having been denied permission to do so by lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The US lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Federal lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Communications lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Commission.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Second, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The number of objects in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">heavens is about to rocket. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The UN’s lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Office for lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Outer lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Affairs says about 8,650 objects have been launched into lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space since lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Sputnik went up in 1957. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">SpaceX, a rocketry firm, alone has plans to launch more than 12,000 in a lass="word-wrap-span">constellation of small satellites known as Starlink. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Olass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">constellations are planned. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space tourism may well add to lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The amount of traffic to be managed.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">These lass="word-wrap-span">constellations are needed because lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The satellites will be in low-lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth orbit (lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">LEO). lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">bulk of satellite communications today comes through objects in a lass="word-wrap-span">geostationary orbit, some 36,000km above lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth. At that lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">altitude a satellite takes a day to travel around lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The planet, seeming to lass="word-wrap-span">hover in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The same place. At a lower orbit, lots of satellites are needed to maintain coverage of a specific area; lass="word-wrap-span">constellations will lass="word-wrap-span">criss-cross each olass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther as lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They whizz around lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The world.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Floating in a most peculiar way

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The rules are clear for objects that stay in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The same location, says lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ruth Pritchard-lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Kelly of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">OneWeb, an operator which has six lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">LEO satellites in orbit already and plans eventually to launch at a rate of 30 a month until its lass="word-wrap-span">constellation is complete. “lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There are an lass="word-wrap-span">infinite number of ways for an object to be non-lass="word-wrap-span">geostationary. We have to come up with rules on how to share space.” An ITU conference in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Egypt in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">October and November will try to do just that.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Liability rules also need refreshing. A 1972 regime lass="word-wrap-span">assigns lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Liability lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">For damage caused by a space object based on who launched it. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">That made more sense in an era when governments launched lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their own objects from lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their own territory. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Take lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">collision in 2009 between a lass="word-wrap-span">defunct lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Russian military satellite called Kosmos-2251 and an operational commercial satellite called lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Iridium 33. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Iridium 33 was owned by an lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American firm but it was launched from a lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Russian-owned spaceport. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Had lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There been a claim lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">For lass="word-wrap-span">compensation, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Iridium would have lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Had to call in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">State lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Department to approach lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Russian lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ministry of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Foreign lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Affairs. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Russians could have argued lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">That, since lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Iridium 33 launched from lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Russia, it was in effect lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Russian and this was an internal lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Affair.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Iridium, which ended up not making a claim, would have faced another argument, too: that responsibility for a lass="word-wrap-span">collision lies with the party which had the last opportunity to avoid it. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Working that out is not lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">always easy, and becomes well-nigh impossible if both objects are lass="word-wrap-span">defunct. “If you have two drivers on a road with no traffic lights, no steering wheels and no brakes, who’s at fault if they crash?” asks lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dara Panahy of Milbank, a law firm.

In these circumstances, mitigating the risk of future lass="word-wrap-span">collisions is not enough; it is also necessary to be able to remove lass="word-wrap-span">debris from lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space. A range of technologies, from lass="word-wrap-span">harpoons to tethers to nets, are being developed to do that. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But the practice would require a change in the rules. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">International law states, for example, that an object belongs in perpetuity to the country that launched it. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">James Vedda of the Centre for lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Policy and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Strategy, a research group, argues for an lass="word-wrap-span">equivalent of a maritime-salvage regime, so that it is possible either to recover an object without permission or to get such permission very quickly.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Compared with lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The problem of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">debris, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The legal questions raised by lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space mining are less urgent. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The technological and financial lass="word-wrap-span">hurdles to success are lass="word-wrap-span">immense: companies like lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Planetary lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Resources and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Deep lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space Industries, formed in a lass="word-wrap-span">blaze of publicity to prospect for minerals on lass="word-wrap-span">asteroids, have already stumbled. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The ambition remains, focused clearly on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth’s nearest neighbour.

“If we can utilise resources to keep a community on the lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Moon,” says lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Michelle Hanlon of the lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Air and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Law Programme at the lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">University of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Mississippi lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">School of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Law, “that is our best way to find out how to keep humans in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space for the long term.” At his presentation in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">May, Mr Bezos lass="word-wrap-span">envisaged using ice in the shadowed lass="word-wrap-span">craters of the lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Moon to generate fuel, and targeted a lunar landing by lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Blue lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Origin by 2024. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">NASA plans a lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space station in lunar orbit, from where lass="word-wrap-span">astronauts would operate robotic probes on the surface that could harvest minerals. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">China and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">India both have lunar programmes and, doubtless, similar thoughts.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Some question whelass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther resource lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">extraction would be legal. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Outer lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Treaty prohibits national lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">appropriation in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space. To lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The question “who owns lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Moon?”, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The unambiguous answer is “no one”. In practice, however, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The question is not so much whelass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther mining can happen, but in what circumstances.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">International lawyers point to two, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">admittedly lass="word-wrap-span">imperfect, analogies on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth as ways to think about space mining. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">One is lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The high seas: no nation has sovereignty but you don’t need lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">International permission to lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">extract resources (ie, fish). lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The olass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther template is provided by lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Seabed mining, an activity subject to strict licensing and regulation by an organlass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">ISAtion called lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">International lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Seabed lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Authority (lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">ISA).

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Planet lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Earth is blue

An attempt to set up a lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space lass="word-wrap-span">equivalent of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The seabed-mining regime has already been tried, however, and lass="word-wrap-span">failed to gain traction. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Moon lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Agreement came into force in 1984. It calls for an lass="word-wrap-span">international regime to lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">administer any lass="word-wrap-span">exploitation of lunar resources. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Agreement has only been ratified by 18 countries. “lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Spacefaring states like voluntary standards and non-lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Spacefarers like lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The idea of lass="word-wrap-span">international obligations,” says Patrick Slomski of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Clyde & Co, a law firm. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">These lass="word-wrap-span">divergent interests weaken lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The chances eilass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Moon lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Agreement gaining fresh momentum or of a big, new lass="word-wrap-span">international lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Space treaty.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Instead, the high-seas model is the one that looks likely to prevail. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Both lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Luxembourg, which has long punched above its weight in the satellite and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">aerospace industries, have plass="word-wrap-span">assed legislation that lass="word-wrap-span">explicitly allow firms lass="word-wrap-span">incorporated on their territories to carry out space mining; the lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">United Arab lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Emirates is about to follow suit. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Proponents of the high-seas approach like the fact that it allows commercial firms to act fast. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">But unbridled competition for resources is also a recipe for trouble. If a lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Chinese miner and an lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">American one were to set up shop next door to each other on the lunar surface, say, lass="word-wrap-span">domestic laws would be no help in resolving any conflict that might result.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">That argues for co-ordination and common standards. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The award of licences by national authorities could be notified to an lass="word-wrap-span">international body modelled on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The ITU’s radio-lass="word-wrap-span">frequency regime for satellites. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Rules could usefully be set for lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">duration of mining licences, for lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The placement of lass="word-wrap-span">buffer zones around mining sites and for lass="word-wrap-span">dispute-resolution processes.

Ms Hanlon, who also runs an NGO class="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Alled lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">For lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">All lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Moonkind, suggests an even narrower goal: an agreement on common lunar landing-pads in order to protect lass="word-wrap-span">historic sites such as the landing area of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Apollo 11 in 1969. “We are not going to agree a treaty in the next five years, but we can take baby steps,” she says. 为了避免饿死和不进监狱，一个人应当尊重公众意见，但是除了这些目的之外如果还这么做，那就是对不必要专制的自愿遵从。
